snippet: Despite its reverence for tradition, Japan has an ambivalent — and unsentimental — relationship with its Modernist architecture. Why preparing for the future sometimes means destroying the past.
abstract: Three high-profile and controversial demolition jobs around Tokyo, in which 1960s buildings like Hotel Okura are being torn down in favor of more futuristic structures, highlight Japan's often  ambivalent relationship with mid-century modernist architecture.
lead_paragraph: Despite its reverence for tradition, Japan has an ambivalent — and unsentimental — relationship with its Modernist architecture. Why preparing for the future sometimes means destroying the past.

headline.main: In Japan, History Has No Place
